content: So, I'm upgrading from D7 to Backdrop and could need some live help.
Current state: everything prepared, and now I try to run update.php.
On update.php I'm not allowed to continue because of a requirements problem: I get the message "Directory public://css_injector is not writable".
Was css injector still enabled in Drupal?
I guess you could try creating that directory in /files?
Yes, it was enabled.
And the directory files/css_injector exists.
Check the permissions on it...?
Permissions look fine to me: 755
(not an expert, but I've also tried 777 to be sure)
Can you see if the files directory is actually set to /files?
No, not sure where.
However, I guess the issue has to do how I've set up the files directory...
If you haven't run update.php yet and converted everything to config, then I think it should be stored in the variables table of the database
Ideally that should be disabled before running the main site update, I think.
Then reactivated and run update for modules. IIRC

I followed most steps of https://backdropcms.org/upgrade-from-drupal, here Step 3, no 2., the recommended approach to move the files over to Backdrop:

  • Copy the files directory from Drupal 7 (usually drupal/sites/default/files) into the Backdrop site (usually backdrop/files)
  • Create a default directory within backdrop/sites.
  • Create a symlink in your filesystem from sites/default/files to files .
Suspecting something went wrong with the symlink. Is there a way to check if the symlink works?

Created the symlink this way:

  • mkdir /sites/default
  • ln -s /files /sites/default/files
@laryn Why do you think CSS Injector should be disabled in Drupal?

@Olaf Grabienski I think you need to:

cd /sites/default
ln -s ../../files files

it should be stored in the variables table of the database

Do you know the command to find it using phpMyAdmin?

`ln -s ../../files files``

Hm, isn't that a symlink from files to files?
If you run that from the /sites/default directory, it should create a link called files which points to ../../files (the files directory in the root).
I can see my symlink via Filezilla, it's in /sites/default and from what the symbol looks like, it points to files.
I thought one of the first steps was disable (but don't uninstall) all not-core modules you want to use on the Backdrop site. But it's been a little while since I did an upgrade at this point...
I assumed it was so any module updates ran after any core updates.
@Laryn is correct. Non-core modules should be disabled first. Just means less errors/issues up front.
@Olaf Grabienski If you can access /sites/default/files/[filename].jpg and it works, then it should be fine.

Hm, on https://packweb.eu/blog/migrating-drupal-7-backdrop-cms I read: "Delete all modules in the 'Contrib' category from the filesystem. Don't disable or uninstall them." ;-?

Migrating from Drupal 7 to Backdrop CMS
We've been upgrading a few of our client's Drupal 7 sites to Backdrop CMS recently (read why here), so we thought we'd share with you the process we're using. The official Backdrop instructions can be found on the 'Upgrading from Drupal 7' page; ours are based on those instructions, but with some changes that we find fit better with our workflow.
That's because I'm lazy and the sites I migrate are fairly simple :smiling_face: Are you following my instructions or Backdrop's? I don't think you can pick and choose steps from each...

@BWPanda I've read both instructions and tried to understand everything. However, even on https://backdropcms.org/upgrade-from-drupal there's nothing about disabling contrib modules. Only thing there: "Disable and uninstall core modules that have been removed from Backdrop CMS that you no longer need."

If you can access /sites/default/files/[filename].jpg and it works, then it should be fine.

Well, that doesn't work. I get a "Forbidden" 403 error for /sites/default/files/image.jpg, but /files/image.jpg shows the image!
So, issue seems to be the symlink.
So your symlink doesn't work then. Try my suggestion above re. that.
Trying ...

• ln -s ../../files files
  • ln: failed to create symbolic link 'files': File exists
You know how to remove my former one?
rm /sites/default/files
Or rm -r /sites/default/files if it complains that it's a directory
Great, now I can access /sites/default/files/image.jpg via the browser.
But CSS Injector directory still "Not writable" :-/
Guess I'll disable CSS Injector and try again.

Ok, I've disabled CSS Injector in Drupal. Unfortunately, when I continue, I get this frustrating error:

"DatabaseSchemaObjectExistsException: Cannot rename languages to language: table language already exists. in DatabaseSchema_mysql->renameTable() (line 313 of [...])/core/includes/database/mysql/schema.inc)."
^^^Has anyone heard of this? ^^
Oh, the Database exception was probably my fault: Didn't remove all database tables before importing the database without CSS injector enabled.
Now I'll see if the "208 pending updates" will run!
Phew, database updates ran without problem, and the site is still up. There were some messages, will dig into it later. Thanks @Laryn and @BWPanda for supporting me!
Did I mention it? Upgrading to Backdrop makes me always nervous. And I think the docs are not good. Hard to make them better, though.

There is no such thing as "perfect" documentation ...especially since software gets updated, and also because there are so many moving parts. Producing good documentation is an iterative process, so everyone's feedback and improvements is welcomed :wink:
And different people have different approaches with the upgrade. I seem to recall @jenlampton recommends having all the modules enabled and new code bases before running update.php.

Yep! I do one final update at the end with everything in place (just like
you do with Drupal) but I usually also do a few before that as tests, I'm
various stages of enabledness.
I guess what would help me, is doing such upgrades more often! Btw, @klonos have you in the meantime tried to do a D7 to Backdrop upgrade?
I have not @Olaf Grabienski ...via the agency I work for, I have access to the db/files/codebase of so many D7 sites, but have never actually done that. Shame on me :sweat:
...I am mostly interested in fixing UX/UI issues in core, and I seem to be always drawn to those. I simply don't have time for other things then.
No worries, @klonos

Webform or upgrade experts: In an website upgrade from D7 to Backdrop, most Webform settings were empty, and the content type didn't have webform functionality. Before fixing the settings, I got a blank page on admin/content/webform. Looking at a webform node I saw the node but no webform components. After fixing the settings, I get a PDO exception even on admin/content:

SQLSTATE[42S22]: Column not found: 1054 Unknown column 'webform_roles.role' in 'field list': SELECT webform_roles.role AS role FROM {webform_roles} webform_roles WHERE (nid = :db_condition_placeholder_0) ; Array ( [:db_condition_placeholder_0] => 379 ) in webform_node_load() (line 1778 of /.../modules/webform/webform.module).

Sounds familiar to anyone?
(Have to run now but will be back online in a couple of hours.)
Doesn't sound familiar but I will be following as I have a project upcoming that has some complex webforms... Is it a multilingual site?

Doesn't sound familiar, but I have a suspicion: in webform_update_1601() the column rid should have been changed to role and varchar type. As this column doesn't seem to exist now, either the update hook failed or wasn't run at all.

Did you see any errors regarding that db table when upgrading?
@Laryn It's not multilingual (but localized, German default language). Neither the website nor the one webform used on the site are very complex.

@indigoxela I don't recall any errors regarding Webform, but looking at the notices from update.php (saved them as text for reference), Webform got no updates at all during the upgrade! Same happened btw with Override Node Options and References. How can this be?

Now when I think about it again (did the upgrade more than a week ago), it might be that at first I forgot to download two or three contrib modules for Backdrop before running update.php. (Not sure which ones and when exactly I added them.) Would that explain the behavior?

Would that explain the behavior?

At least it sounds plausible.
Indeed! Will run the upgrade again tomorrow.

Olaf, have you tried rebuilding one of the forms and see if that fixes it? I don't normally do upgrades with complex sites, I migrate them, so I havent' had this issue.

it might be that at first I forgot to download two or three contrib modules for Backdrop before running update.php. (Not sure which ones and when exactly I added them.) Would that explain the behavior?

@Olaf Grabienski yes, all modules need to be present before you run update.php. Some modules need to run their updates before the core updates run, so they all need to be there at the same time. If you have a clean D7 database, I'd recommend starting over from there (but save all your config! You can sync that again when you are done)

@Elisabeth Garbeil Thanks! Rebuilding the webform would be interesting but I guess in this situation it makes more sense to give the upgrade another try. Re migrating sites instead of upgrading: Which tools and which workflow do you use for migrations?
So, I started over (and downloaded all contrib modules before running update.php), and the Webform issue is fixed, yay! Thanks everyone!!

@Olaf Grabienski,

We’re typically updating and redesigning the site when we migrate, so mainly I use the same tools you would to develop a new site. That’s one of the reasons we don’t just upgrade. We tend not to use drush or composer because we’re a small shop that’s been around a long time and does more than just Drupal, so I have my own scripts. I tried out drush a long time ago and it wasn’t worth the effort for us. If you want to use one of those, I would recommend composer over drush. It’s less overhead in my experience. I use primarily feeds and some custom coding to migrate data from D6 or D7 to Backdrop. I don’t typically bring over anything but content. I recreate the webforms manually, since there’s usually only one or two. The one migration where there were a lot, we revamped the forms anyway, so I would have had to redo them.

We’re not using D8 or D9 at all. It’s too expensive a footprint for any of our clients with no benefit. Hope that helps!

I’ve run into a couple of wrinkles with feeds, but have gotten lots of help on Zulip, so there haven’t ever been any showstoppers with that. I’m pretty happy with it.

Good luck with your upgrade!

Warmest regards,

Elisabeth Garbeil, MBA PMP

If you are running an install profile other than the core 'standard' profile, make sure you have a Backdrop version of that profile, or switch to the standard profile in Drupal 7.

@Sarvasri Whenever searching for a module, theme, layout, etc. and you can't find it in Backdrop's "Project Installer" or on BackdropCMS.org, search GitHub: https://github.com/backdrop-contrib Often there'll be projects (like this one) that don't have a release (hence they don't appear in Backdrop) but you can still download and use them.

Do I copy the Go to file button link? i.e. right click on Go To File and grab the URL? I don't know how to move it to Drupal.org so I can get it the usual way I get modules.
It is, yes.
It needs to be moved/copied to Drupal.org...

@Sarvasri - You don't need GIT. You can just download the module with this link , decompress it, and put it in the sites/all/modules directory. https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/backdrop_upgrade_status/archive/7.x-1.x.zip

Actually:
1) Download the module
2) Decompress it
3) Change the directory name to remove any extra version information. For example. change "backdrop_upgrade_status-7.x-1.x" to "backdrop_upgrade_status"
4) Drop it in the sites/all/modules/ directory for your Drupal site.

@StPaulTim , I started the process of looking into what it will take to port my D7 site, making a list of the ~70 D7 contrib modules, going through the BD docs, and searching module-by-module through the BD module repository for ports. That worked, but after seeing this thread, I went and installed backdrop_upgrade_status and it worked like a charm, giving the relevant information almost instantaneously. I would have loved to have led with that! So let me put in my vote for getting it up on Drupal.org (even at the risk of fragility); I think the benefit to folks wondering what to do outweighs any risks.

It seems to me, based on this thread, that the bigger issue is that it's not (well) documented. Whether it's on d.o or not doesn't really matter, if there's sufficient documentation to guide people to it and its proper use.

@bugfolder there's an issue proposed for the backdrop_upgrade_status that would allow site maintainers such as yourself, to manually submit the list of modules you use on Drupal 7 to the Backdrop team so they can begin compiling a list of which ones to prioritize.

From your perspective, what do you think would be the best way to get others such as yourself to be highly motivated to submit this data?

@oadaeh (Jason Flatt), agreed that that's an issue. Putting a link to that prominently on the Backdrop main page (something like "Wondering whether to migrate from D7 to Backdrop? Use this tool [link]" might help. I seem to recall that there was (is) a D7->D8 upgrade availability module (and the carnage I saw when I ran it was a powerful argument for moving to Backdrop). Perhaps pointing to both modules: "compare migrating to BD vs D8 on your D7 site" would be helpful.

@Phil Ward, if that backdrop_upgrade_status module offered a one-click button "submit a list of my needed contrib modules to the Backdrop team" on the same availability results page, that might get people to submit since anyone looking at upgrade status is probably somewhat motivated to make their needs known.

@bugfolder yeah, that's kind of what I was thinking too. I brought up the idea of automating it in the background, but that didn't go over too well for privacy reasons. I think a submit button is probably good enough and I agree it should be at the top of that status page.
